verses.text: A wife of noble character who can find? She is worth far more than rubies.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 31:10–31
rsbNotes.text: 31:10–31 This section is an acrostic poem extolling the virtues of a wife who exemplifies the principles of wisdom, both practically and spiritually. The sequence of virtues is governed more by the demands of the acrostic (the first word in each verse beginning with successive letters of the alphabet) than by logic. Yet the overall effect is of a coherent description of a woman beautified by her virtues of practical wisdom and charity. That the household described is well-to-do does not detract from the universal applicability of the principles of wifely wisdom.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 31:10
rsbNotes.text: 31:10 who can find. Such a wife is not an impossible dream, but may be hard to find.

verses.text: Her husband has full confidence in her and lacks nothing of value.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 31:11
rsbNotes.text: 31:11 no lack of gain. This state of affairs results from the wife’s astuteness in household affairs.

verses.text: She brings him good, not harm, all the days of her life.
She selects wool and flax and works with eager hands.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 31:12
rsbNotes.text: 31:12 See 18:22 and notes.

verses.text: She is like the merchant ships, bringing her food from afar.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 31:14
rsbNotes.text: 31:14 like the ships of the merchant. As vv. 16, 18 indicate, she engages in commerce.

verses.text: She gets up while it is still dark; she provides food for her family and portions for her servant girls.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 31:15
rsbNotes.text: 31:15 portions. Either food or duties.

verses.text: She considers a field and buys it; out of her earnings she plants a vineyard.
She sets about her work vigorously; her arms are strong for her tasks.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 31:16
rsbNotes.text: 31:16 She is able in business and reinvests her earnings.

verses.text: She sees that her trading is profitable, and her lamp does not go out at night.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 31:18
rsbNotes.text: 31:18 Her lamp does not go out. This is either a metaphor for prosperity (13:9), or a reference to her diligence in using the hours of dark for work.

verses.text: In her hand she holds the distaff and grasps the spindle with her fingers.
She opens her arms to the poor and extends her hands to the needy.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 31:19
rsbNotes.text: 31:19 distaff. The meaning is uncertain. The context indicates ability to make her own thread.

verses.text: When it snows, she has no fear for her household; for all of them are clothed in scarlet.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 31:21
rsbNotes.text: 31:21 scarlet. If “scarlet” is the correct reading, it probably indicates high quality cloth that is very warm.

verses.text: She makes coverings for her bed; she is clothed in fine linen and purple.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 31:22
rsbNotes.text: 31:22 fine linen and purple. As in v. 21, high quality articles are in view.

verses.text: Her husband is respected at the city gate, where he takes his seat among the elders of the land.
She makes linen garments and sells them, and supplies the merchants with sashes.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 31:23
rsbNotes.text:
31:23 The implication is that the wife’s skill and diligence in home affairs remove all concerns about them from her husband. He is free to pursue his place as a respected elder in public life.

in the gates. See 1:21 and note.
